Slavery on Screen,Seminar,,J,,englisch,2022-04-20,2022-07-20,,"14:00","16:00",Mittwoch,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Elahe Haschemi Yekani,Seminarraum 1.501,"5. OG ",Dorotheenstraße 24 ,Universitätsgebäude am Hegelplatz,Technische Abteilung (V),"

How can the traumatic history of enslavement be represented in film and on TV? In this seminar, we will look at foundational artefacts from TV and film culture. In the United States, the TV series Roots (1977) was one of the first attempts to acknowledge trauma and provide narrative agency to the depicted enslaved characters. Contrasting feature films and TV series, we will analyse how different commemorative practices have emerged since the late 1970s until now. In this endeavour, we will also discuss the increasing aesthetic range in visual representations of slavery from more traditional depictions in historical drama such as Stephen Spielberg&rsquo
column3: s Amazing Grace (2006), to Quentin Tarantino&rsquo
column7: s body cinema in 12 Years A Slave (2013) and more recently The Underground Railroad (2021). In addition to the close reading of these visual materials, students will also be familiarised with theoretical concepts such as Paul Gilroy&rsquo

column1:
It is strongly recommended to watch at least some of the shows/films before the new semester starts. A reader and access to Moodle with further material will be provided at the beginning of the class.

column2: erotischer Briefroman Les Liaisons Dangereuses (1782) stehen. In den 175 Briefen, die zwischen den Romanfiguren zirkulieren, geht es um Verfü
column4: bung von Macht durch Beherrschung von Sprache. Wer sich in den rhetorischen Fallstricken seiner Briefpartner verf&auml
column6: sidente de Tourvel, hat wenig zu lachen und bald auch nichts mehr zu sagen. Wer nicht schreiben kann, wie die naive C&eacute
column7: cile, wird zum Spielball erotischer Phantasien. Wer die Sprachen der Liebe mit all ihren Raffinessen beherrscht, wie der Vicomte de Valmont und die Marquise de Merteuil, liefert sich erbitterte Gefechte, in denen sexuelles Begehren, Hass und Machtstreben ineinander fallen.

Culture and Media: The Cultural Study of U.S. Immigration Law,Seminar,,J,,englisch,2022-04-21,2022-07-21,,"12:00","14:00",Donnerstag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Jasper Verlinden,Seminarraum 2.102,"1. OG ",Dorotheenstraße 24 ,Universitätsgebäude am Hegelplatz,Technische Abteilung (V),"

Immigration has been a highly debated and controversial topic for many years, following the displacement of large numbers of people due to war, persecution, or economic hardship, all of which has been exacerbated by the global pandemic. In the US specifically, the Trump administration has brought questions around immigration acutely to the fore with such issues as the border wall between the US and Mexico, the so-called &ldquo
column3: and the ICE (Immigration and Customs Enforcement) detention centers. In each of these cases, the legality of these measures has been questioned and contested.

column1: In this seminar, we will approach legal frameworks around immigration from a cultural studies perspective. We will look at the history of immigration law and some of its precursors (such as the Alien and Sedition Acts of 1798 and the policies and regulations around the reservation system). In addition, we will discuss such topics as undocumented migration, citizenship, deportation, and sanctuary cities, as well as the roles that race, class, gender, and sexuality play in these issues.

Rather than simply considering specific instances of immigration law, however, we will also ask what law actually is and what it does, and how we can approach it from a cultural studies perspective. The course materials for this seminar will include legal history and theory, critical race theory, border studies, films and documentaries, and cultural theory.

column1: Problemfelder des Fremdsprachenlehrens und &#8211
column2:
lernens: Mehrsprachigkeit und Mehrkulturalität im Fremdsprachenunterricht,Seminar,,N,,deutsch,,,,"10:00","12:00",Donnerstag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Nevena Stamenkovic,Seminarraum 1.403,"4. OG ",Dorotheenstraße 24 ,Universitätsgebäude am Hegelplatz,Technische Abteilung (V),"

In den letzten Jahren und insbesondere seit der Forderung des Europarats nach einem mehrsprachigen Europa im Jahr 2001 hat die Fremdsprachendidaktik vielfä
column3: ltige Konzepte entwickelt, um die individuelle Mehrsprachigkeit der Sch&uuml
column5: rdern. Im Seminar werden grundlegende Konzepte und Ans&auml
column6: tze der Mehrsprachigkeitsdidaktik vorgestellt, um davon ausgehend konkrete M&ouml
column7: glichkeiten ihrer didaktisch-methodischen Umsetzung im Fremdsprachenunterricht der Sekundarstufen I und II zu diskutieren. Dabei wird insbesondere auf die Frage eingegangen, welches Potenzial die romanischen Sprachen f&uuml
column9: rderung des sprach- und kulturvernetzenden Lernens haben und welche M&ouml
column10: glichkeiten es gibt, die Herkunftssprachen der Sch&uuml
column11:
lerInnen einzubeziehen. Es werden sowohl kognitiv-analytische (z.B. aus dem Bereich der Interkomprehensionsdidaktik) als auch kreativ-produktive Verfahren (z.B. anhand von mehrsprachiger Literatur) vorgestellt und erprobt.

"

Empfindsamkeit in der skandinavischen Literatur,Seminar,,N,,deutsch,2022-07-15,2022-07-15,,"12:00","14:00",Freitag,Einzeltermin,Einzeltermin,Otto Fischer,Besprechungsraum 3.231,"2. OG ",Dorotheenstraße 24 ,Universitätsgebäude am Hegelplatz,"Sprach- und literaturwissenschaftliche Fakultät, Nordeuropa-Institut","

In diesem Kurs wird die sogenannte empfindsame Literatur des 18. Jahrhunderts im skandinavischen Kulturraum dargestellt und diskutiert. Das Hauptanliegen des Kurses ist es, die wichtigsten Werke dieser Zeit in ihrem geschichtlichen und gesellschaftlichen Zusammenhang zu betrachten, wobei die Schwerpunkte auf sozial-, medien- und emotionsgeschichtlichen Perspektiven liegen. Verschiedene Perspektiven aus der heutigen Forschung werden vorgestellt, und eine literatur- und kulturgeschichtliche Entwicklung innerhalb des skandinavischen Kulturkreises wird gezeichnet. Der Kurs wird als Blockseminar geboten, was bedeutet, dass nebst zwei Vorlesungsmomenten, besteht er aus drei Freitag-Samstagsitzungen (4 Stunden pro Tag, Freitag und Samstag). Diese Sitzungen beinhalten Referate und gemeinsame Diskussion.

"

Contemporary North American Novels,Seminar,,N,,englisch,2022-04-19,2022-07-19,,"16:00","18:00",Dienstag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Eva Boesenberg,Seminarraum 1.501,"5. OG ",Dorotheenstraße 24 ,Universitätsgebäude am Hegelplatz,Technische Abteilung (V),"

In different ways, North American novels published in the last ten years respond to and engage with contemporary cultural and political developments while also grappling with the legacies of US and Canadian history. Invariably, they examine and rewrite social hierarchies based on 'race,' class, gender, sexuality, ability, etc., frequently mobilizing innovative narrative techniques in this connection. Together, they offer a multi-faceted portrayal of the current North American cultural landscape while testifying to the ongoing vitality of North American literary traditions.

Credit for the course requires reading excerpts from the novels (and one entire text), participating in class discussions, and organizing one session (together with some fellow-students).

"

column1:
The London Flaneur,Seminar,,N,,englisch,2022-04-21,2022-07-21,,"14:00","16:00",Donnerstag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Jennifer Wawrzinek,Hörsaal 3075,"2. OG ",Unter den Linden 6 ,Universitäts-Hauptgebäude,Technische Abteilung (V),"

In his 1863 essay &ldquo
column3: , Charles Baudelaire describes the figure of the fl&acirc
column4: neur as the archetypal observer of Modernity, strolling the streets of Paris to transmute experience into art. Walter Benjamin later describes the fl&acirc
column5: neur as a modern artist-poet, keenly aware of the bustle of modern life, an amateur detective and investigator of the city, but also a sign of the city and of capitalism. For Baudelaire and Benjamin, the fl&acirc
column6: neur is not only a literary figure, but one that is distinctly French, male, and associated with a burgeoning Parisian urban culture. Yet by the beginning of the nineteenth century, it was London, not Paris, that was the largest urban centre within Europe, counting over one million citizens by 1801 and expanding to one and a half million within the first decade of the century. It is no surprise, therefore, that London writers also explored the changing shape of the city and its burgeoning consumer cultures through the figure of the stroller, who explores the streets of London to reflect on the changing shape of the city and its relationship to the emerging British Empire. Using Benjamin&rsquo
column13:
, this course will examine writings by early-nineteenth-century urban peripatetics who took to the streets of London as observers of everyday life. Students will be asked to consider the ways in which strolling, walking and loitering can be seen in these texts as disruptions and/or refigurations of the space-time of the burgeoning British nation and its consolidation of national and imperial identity, inscriptions and/or destabilisations of urban space in terms of gender and class, as well as negotiations of emerging forms of commodity capitalism.

"

column1:
Sociology of Architecture (ÜWP),Seminar,,N,,englisch,2022-07-21,2022-07-21,,"10:00","12:00",Donnerstag,Einzeltermin,Einzeltermin,Johannes Coughlan,Hörsaal 1 207,"2. OG ",Dorotheenstraße 26 ,Institutsgebäude,Technische Abteilung (V),"

In recent decades, a growing interest in material cultures and the sociology of space has elevated the
column2: status of architecture in sociological discussions. In this seminar, we will ask how different architectural forms take part in a range of different social practices. To what extent are they part of social practices, support or suppress them? We will adopt a simple scheme of spatial directions to discuss forms of enclosure (prisons), verticality (skyscrapers), liminality (borders), flows (logistics), etc. The seminar will take place in English. Students will be required to write reading&nbsp
column4:
meeting and to either write a book review or record one as a podcast.

"

column1:
Oral Skills: Part of the Panel,Übung,,N,,englisch,2022-04-19,2022-07-19,,"12:00","14:00",Dienstag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Eimear Kelly,Seminarraum (ehem. 0109) 0007,EG ,Hausvogteiplatz 5-7 ,Institutsgebäude,Technische Abteilung (V),"

In recognition of the importance of oral/aural skills for language students, this course uses short stories by British, Irish and American authors to develop skills such as recognizing context clues, listening for detail and using advanced grammatical structures. After listening to the podcasts, students are required to complete a certain number of exercises designed to cultivate their listening and speaking skills in a creative manner.

Registration for this course via AGNES.

"

Oral Skills: Social Media/Social Justice Movements in the US: #MeToo and #BLM,Übung,,N,,englisch,2022-04-22,2022-07-22,,"16:00","18:00",Freitag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,,Seminarraum 1.501,"5. OG ",Dorotheenstraße 24 ,Universitätsgebäude am Hegelplatz,Technische Abteilung (V),"

In this course students will develop their active seminar skills in English through discussion, presentations and debates on cultural issues around #Metoo and #BlackLivesMatter. Participants will have the opportunity to build confidence in respectfully arguing their views, to develop strategies for engaging with colleagues' arguments, and to acquire appropriate academic vocabulary.
Please register by

Essay Composition,Übung,,N,,englisch,2022-04-20,2022-07-20,,"10:00","12:00",Mittwoch,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Michael Davies,Seminarraum 1.502,"5. OG ",Dorotheenstraße 24 ,Universitätsgebäude am Hegelplatz,Technische Abteilung (V),"

In this course, students will familiarize themselves with the genre of the English essay, investigating academic norms, textual dimensions, styles and techniques commonly encountered in various essay types. They will critically analyse selected English essays belonging to the categories reflective-discursive, argumentative and descriptive and write extended essays of their own to practise using the style and conventions of each type. There will be a focus on literary, cultural and philosophical themes. In addition to working upon their own essay writing skills, students will have an opportunity to review and discuss essays written by their peers throughout the course.
This course will involve blended learning.

Interested students should send an email to michael.davies@hu-berlin.de by Wednesday, 13th April 2022 and include details of language courses they have already attended in modules 1a and 1b of the MA English Literatures programme.

Written Expression: UK Topics,Übung,,N,,englisch,2022-04-20,2022-07-20,,"12:00","14:00",Mittwoch,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Michael Davies,PC-Pool 1.305,"3. OG ",Dorotheenstraße 24 ,Universitätsgebäude am Hegelplatz,Sprach- und literaturwissenschaftliche Fakultät,"

In this course, students will have an opportunity to extend and improve their own written competence in English by analysing and critically interacting with a broad range of texts relating to current political, social and cultural themes in Britain. In addition to producing written responses of their own to the topics dealt with, students will also work on improving accuracy of expression and stylistic appropriacy in English and reflect upon how they would deal with the topics discussed in the course within the school curriculum.
This course will involve blended learning.
column2:
Interested students should register by Wednesday 13th April 2022 using the form on the MAEd English Sprachpraxis Course Registration SoSe 2022 Moodle page. The password is sprchprxs22

"

column1:
Intercultural Textuality,Übung,,N,,englisch,2022-04-19,2022-07-19,,"14:00","16:00",Dienstag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Michael Davies,Seminarraum 2004A,"1. OG ",Unter den Linden 6 ,Universitäts-Hauptgebäude,Technische Abteilung (V),"

In this course, students will practise developing their spoken and written competence in English in a variety of contexts including participating in discussions and debates on literary/cultural themes and writing texts of their own in the areas of fiction, non-fiction and creative writing. The focus will be on finding just the right words, tone and style to communicate naturally and effectively in different spoken/authorial situations using the textual dynamics and cultural codes of English.
This course will involve blended learning.

Interested students should send an email to michael.davies@hu-berlin.de by Wednesday, 13th April 2022 and include details of language courses they have already attended in modules 1a and 1b of the MA English Literatures programme.

"

Culture and Language Learning,Übung,,N,,englisch,2022-04-19,2022-07-19,,"12:00","14:00",Dienstag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Michael Davies,Seminarraum 1.404,"4. OG ",Dorotheenstraße 24 ,Universitätsgebäude am Hegelplatz,Technische Abteilung (V),"

In this course, students will reflect upon how to develop cultural competence at different levels of the curriculum and take a hands-on approach to devising and presenting a cultural lesson of their own that could be implemented in an English classroom. In addition to investigating crucial didactic and methodological issues involved in developing &lsquo
column5: cultural knowledge, the course will also deal with how to adjust instructional language and classroom discourse to different age and ability levels and how to select and use cultural materials effectively in heterogeneous classrooms.

column1: This course will involve blended learning.
Interested students should register by Thursday 13th
column2:
April 2022 using the form on the MAEd English Sprachpraxis Course Registration SoSe 2022 Moodle page. The password is sprchprxs22

"

column1:
Research Methods (Linguistics),Seminar,,N,,englisch,2022-04-21,2022-07-21,,"12:00","14:00",Donnerstag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,,Hörsaal 2014B,"1. OG ",Unter den Linden 6 ,Universitäts-Hauptgebäude,Technische Abteilung (V),"

In this course, we will deal with methods used in modern linguistics such as in formal-grammar, psycholinguistics and sociolinguistics. We will focus on a selection of research topics and questions at the interface of syntax, semantics, pragmatics, with cross-linguistic and interdialectal (i.e. among different varieties of English) as well as inter/intra-individual comparisons (i.e. the individual differences in linguistic behavior and the underlying mechanism). The course will prepare you methodologically for writing your BA thesis in linguistics, independently of your choice of the subject matter.

"

An Existential Reading of the Torah/Hebrew Bible (HS H 653, MEd E, MRC- V2d,V4b,V4c),Seminar,,N,,englisch,2022-04-26,,,"18:00","20:00",Dienstag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Tsvi Blanchard,Seminarraum 113,"1. OG ",Burgstraße 26 ,Institutsgebäude,Technische Abteilung (V),"

In this course, we will study narrative and legal sections of the Hebrew Bible, focusing on classic existential themes: individuality, meaning, anxiety, and death. Our approach will be oriented to personal growth and development. The course will be taught in English.

"

Lektüreseminar ("Ausgewählte Epochen"),Seminar,,N,,englisch,2022-04-20,2022-07-20,,"10:00","12:00",Mittwoch,"14tgl.","14tgl.",Selma Bidlingmaier,Seminarraum 1.601,"6. OG ",Dorotheenstraße 24 ,Universitätsgebäude am Hegelplatz,Technische Abteilung (V),"

In this course, which is offered in conjunction with the lecture on American Literary History from World War I until today, we will look more closely at selected texts from literary Modernism to early 21st century literature. Specifically, we will situate the works in their historical contexts and discuss salient themes as well as narrative technique. In order to receive credit for this course, you have to read the texts, contribute to class discussions, take part in a group presentation of a specific text or complete a similar task, and in some cases pass a certain number of pop quizzes .

"

In order to receive credit for this course, you have to read the texts, contribute to class discussions, take part in a group presentation of a specific text or complete a similar task, and in some cases pass a certain number of pop quizzes .

"

Pedagogic Grammar,Übung,,N,,englisch,2022-04-19,2022-07-19,,"10:00","12:00",Dienstag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Michael Davies,Seminarraum 1.502,"5. OG ",Dorotheenstraße 24 ,Universitätsgebäude am Hegelplatz,Technische Abteilung (V),"

In this practical course, students will look at how to develop grammatical competence in the classroom from the perspective of pupils acquiring grammar as part of overall language ability. Students will investigate the different types and causes of errors typically encountered in spoken and written output and reflect upon how teachers can provide and adapt grammatical input to meet the needs of different learner types. Key concerns throughout the course will be how to impart grammatical knowledge as part of communicative competence, how to make valid and reliable assessments of language ability in testing situations, and how to develop feedback strategies that enable pupils to learn from their grammatical errors.
The Tuesday course (10 - 12) will involve blended-learning. The Friday course (12 - 14) will be taught digitally.

Interested students should register by Thursday 13th April 2022 using the form on the MAEd English Sprachpraxis Course Registration SoSe 2022 Moodle page. The password is sprchprxs22

"

In this seminar students will be familiarised with the specific British history of the transatlantic slave trade and the African diaspora in Britain and the Caribbean. We will interrogate so-called neo-slave narratives such as Fred D&rsquo
column3: s Feeding the Ghosts, Caryl Phillips&rsquo
column5: s The Long Song and Sara Collins&rsquo
column6:
The Confessions of Frannie Langton. How is Britishness shaped in relation to the legacy of enslavement in contemporary (postmodern) novels? In addition to the literary texts, we will also address commemorative practices in museums etc. regarding the 2007 bicentennial of the abolition of the slave trade.

"

CM06 / Modul 6: SE Advanced Longitudinal Data Analysis,Seminar,https://moodle.hu-berlin.de/course/view.php?id=110248,J,,englisch,2022-04-25,2022-07-18,,"15:00","17:00",Montag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Manuel Völkle,Seminarraum 1.101,"1. OG ",Rudower Chaussee 18 ,Wolfgang-Köhler-Haus,Technische Abteilung (V),"

In this seminar you will learn about state-of-the-art models for longitudinal data analysis in psychology. Based on recent publications in the methodological literature, we will critically reflect on static and dynamic models for the analysis of time series and panel data. Special emphasis will be put on recent developments in continuous time modeling and the modeling of dynamical systems. Depending on time and interest, we will venture into more specialized designs and models such as continuous time mediation models or accelerated longitudinal designs.

"

Literary Representations: The Poetry of Robert Frost,Seminar,,N,,englisch,2022-04-25,2022-07-18,,"16:00","18:00",Montag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Aleksandra Boss,Seminarraum 1.601,"6. OG ",Dorotheenstraße 24 ,Universitätsgebäude am Hegelplatz,Technische Abteilung (V),"

In this seminar, participants will discuss the work of Robert Frost, arguably one of the most influential American poets of the early 20th century. The author of some often-quoted poems such as &ldquo
column4: Stopping by Woods on a Snowy Evening&rdquo
column5: (1923), he received four Pulitzer Prizes and, in 1961, became the first poet asked to recite one of his pieces at a presidential inauguration. Contextualizing Frost&rsquo
column6: s poetry historically, participants will have a forum for the analysis and interpretation of the stylistic features as well as themes and topics of a selection of Frost&rsquo
column7: s texts. The uneasy relationship with Modernism, the impact of related literary movements such as Imagism and Regionalism on his poetry, as well as an exploration and evaluation of his impact on subsequent cultural production will be points of particular interest. Students will receive information regarding the course format and the course requirements at the end of the registration period.

Industrial Organization,Vorlesung/Übung,,N,,englisch,,,,"14:00","16:00",Dienstag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Sebastian Schweighofer-Kodritsch,Hörsaal 202,"2. OG ",Spandauer Straße 1 ,Institutsgebäude,Technische Abteilung (V),"

Learning objectives: The students know the general principles, topics and methods of the economic analysis of industrial organization, based on theoretical models and stylized facts (in particular, case studies). They are familiar with various topics organization and have a deeper understanding of the structure, functioning and outcomes of markets with imperfect competition.

Lecture topics: The theory of the firm, monopoly, oliopoly, collusion, product differentiation, vertical relationships and restraints, mergers, entry and market structure, search and switching costs, two-sided markets, R&
Exercise topics: Solutions to problem sets and discussion of case studies and articles related to the topics from the lecture.
Recommended module or comparable previous knowledge: Mikroö
column4: hrung in die Spieltheorie is helpful but not required (all game theory required beyond Mikro&ouml
column5:
konomie II will be taught in this module).

"

Language Awareness: The Language of Linguistics,Übung,,N,,englisch,2022-04-21,2022-07-21,,"16:00","18:00",Donnerstag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Elisabeth Gibbels,Sprachlabor 325,"3. OG ",Dorotheenstraße 65 ,Boeckh-Haus,Zentraleinrichtung Sprachenzentrum,"

Linguistic approaches feature in many disciplines in an English university curriculum. This course uses short texts from various areas in linguistics, such as stylistics, discourse analysis and pragmatics and investigates their application in literary analysis, media studies and cultural theory. As a side effect, students become familiar with linguistic terminology and can use their favourite theory for their own short response papers. Blended course.

Sex, Race and Taxes (ÜWP),Seminar,,N,,englisch,,,,"10:00","12:00",Dienstag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Manuel Schechtl,Seminarraum 003,EG ,Universitätsstraße 3b ,Institutsgebäude,Technische Abteilung (V),"

Many people think taxes are of purely mathematical concern, or that the study of taxation is of purely economic interest. In other words: they think taxes are boring. Challenging this dominant view, the seminar aims at scrutinising implicit and explicit discrimination based on sexual and racial ascription in the tax code. To this end, we will read and discuss empirical articles from different countries and learn to identify hidden discrimination in tax systems. You don&rsquo
column2: t need specific knowledge of tax practices to participate in the course. However, a willingness to deal with the complexities and &lsquo
column4:
of taxation systems is required. The course will be taught in English.

Thatchers Britain on Film,Seminar,,N,,englisch,2022-04-19,2022-07-19,,"12:00","14:00",Dienstag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Elahe Haschemi Yekani,Seminarraum 1.308,"3. OG ",Dorotheenstraße 24 ,Universitätsgebäude am Hegelplatz,Technische Abteilung (V),"

Margaret Thatcher, who was in office from 1979 to 1990, was the longest-serving British Prime Minister to date. Often referred to simply as the &ldquo
column3: , she was not only the first woman to be elected into the highest office of the state, her economic policies of privatisation, now simply referred to as Thatcherism, paved the way for an enduring neoliberal reordering of British society. These massive social changes were met by enthusiasm by a new upwardly-mobile moneyed middle class and harsh protests by the traditional working-class Left. In this seminar, we will deal with filmic representations that already emerged during Thatcher&rsquo
column4: s time, but also in contemporary British cinema to interrogate the phenomenon of Thatcherism and its impact on events such as the infamous 1984 miners&rsquo
column5: strike (represented in films such as Which Side Are You On? (1985) and more recently Pride (2014)) as well as the historical person Thatcher (e.g. in The Iron Lady (2011)). Students will be introduced to the socio-historical contexts of 1980s Britain (including working-class and youth cultures) and the methodologies of film analysis to cover a broad range of filmic materials.

column1:
It is strongly recommended to watch at least some of the films before the new semester starts. A reader and access to Moodle with further material will be provided at the beginning of the class.

"

Urban Theory,Seminar,,N,,deutsch-englisch,2022-04-21,,,"12:00","14:00",Donnerstag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Andrej Holm,Seminarraum 004,EG ,Universitätsstraße 3b ,Institutsgebäude,Technische Abteilung (V),"

More than half of the world&rsquo
column2: s population lives in cities, and far more people depend on cities for their subsistence. Many see social problems as particular &lsquo
column4: problems, related to the nature of the city and urban life. The urban world has long stimulated sociologists and scholars from related disciplines to think about a large number of issues that constitute urban life or are constituted by urban settings. Some of these issues are typically &lsquo
column6: , some of them merely highly visible in exaggerated forms in the city. Early sociologists saw cities as the ultimate expression of the anonymous industrial society where Gemeinschaft lost its meaning. So from the start, urban sociologists have linked capitalism, urbanism and modernity. In this seminar, we will look at different debates that emerged in urban sociology and related disciplines to understand cities and urban experiences. We will touch on classical urban theory (for example, Chicago School) but will mostly focus on contemporary debates (for example, Global Cities
column7: Social movements and the Right to the City, public space).

column1:
Course language will be German // Der Kurs findet auf deutsch statt.

On this course, we will compare the stylistic conventions of German and English academic texts and analyse typical German-English translation problems. Assignments involve translating and annotating translations in academic contexts such as samples from literary works, book reviews, abstracts, essays, research papers as well as articles from academic journals and newspapers.

Parameterized Algorithms,Vorlesung,,N,,englisch,,,,"11:00","13:00",Dienstag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Stefan Kratsch,Seminarraum 4.113,"1. OG ",Rudower Chaussee 25 ,Johann von Neumann-Haus,Technische Abteilung (V),"

Parameterized algorithms are an approach for coping with the intractability of NP-hard computational problems. The central idea therein is to quantify the structure of input instances by one or more parameters. Then, one seeks algorithms that provably perform well when the chosen parameters are sufficiently small. In this way, we can formalize the intuition that typical instances may have plenty of useful structure, which distinguishes them from the worst case.

There is a rich toolbox of algorithmic techniques that will be covered in the lecture. These include branching algorithms, kernelization, iterative compression, color coding, dynamic programming on tree decompositions, inclusion-exclusion, and others. The algorithmic techniques are complemented by lower bound methods that allow to rule out fast parameterized algorithms or that prove optimality of certain running times under appropriate assumptions.

"

Culture and Media: The Western and Beyond,Seminar,https://moodle.hu-berlin.de/course/view.php?id=110351,J,,englisch,2022-04-19,2022-07-19,,"10:00","12:00",Dienstag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Martin Klepper,Seminarraum 1.308,"3. OG ",Dorotheenstraße 24 ,Universitätsgebäude am Hegelplatz,Technische Abteilung (V),"

Perhaps no other genre symbolizes the ""old"" America, the America of the WASP, the redneck, the economy of conquest and assimilation as much as the Western. In this class we will discuss the mythology of the Western and its historical development from early to classical to revisionist movies and on to today&rsquo
column2: s revival (e.g. Coen-Brothers, Tarantino). Topics for discussion will be the myth of the West, the psychology of the Western, the Western as formula fiction, the topographies of the Western, the times of the Western, the Western and its ethnic Other, the Western and the heterosexual matrix (masculinities, femininities &hellip
column3: ). The theoretical impulses will be supplied by John Cawelti, Richard Slotkin, Gilles Deleuze, Elisabeth Bronfen and others. We will discuss how we can make sure everybody has access to the movies.

Critical Race Theory and Contemporary American Literature,Seminar,,J,,englisch,2022-04-20,2022-07-20,,"14:00","16:00",Mittwoch,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Eva Boesenberg,Seminarraum 1.601,"6. OG ",Dorotheenstraße 24 ,Universitätsgebäude am Hegelplatz,Technische Abteilung (V),"

Racial hierarchies and racial diversity structure North American literature as much as German classrooms. It is thus important to be cognizant of and critically engage with issues of 'race' in a self-reflexive manner.

In this course, we will first look at texts from Critical Race Theory and Critical Whiteness Studies that illuminate contemporary racial dynamics before turning to some fictional works to see how the theories might help illuminate literature. Taking an intersectional approach, we will also analyze how 'race' intersects with other social categories such as gender, sexuality, class, and dis/ability.

Credit for the course requires reading the texts, participating in class discussions, and organizing one session (together with fellow-students).

"

Rethinking Class in Contemporary Fiction,Seminar,,J,,englisch,2022-04-21,2022-07-21,,"10:00","12:00",Donnerstag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Helga Schwalm,Seminarraum 1.501,"5. OG ",Dorotheenstraße 24 ,Universitätsgebäude am Hegelplatz,Technische Abteilung (V),"

Revisiting or rethinking class as a critical category has recently (re-)emerged in literary and cultural studies, and very much so with regard to new millennium fiction. Much attention has been given to new working-class writings
column2: at the same time, critics have also reconsidered representations of the middle class in relation to, for instance, Brexit Lit. and the construction of Britishness, and the question of intersectionality has also been playing a strong role. Accordingly, we shall attempt to explore this range of issues in our seminar by discussing in detail a number of novels that have received strong critical and medial attention. The centrepiece of our coursework will be recent working-class fiction.

column1: Whilst there will be more reading to be done (to be decided upon in class in week I), the core reading so far is as follows:
<ul>
• Douglas Stewart: Shuggie Bain (Picador)
• Bernadine Evaristo: Girl, Woman, Other (Penguin)

Literary Representations: Sentimentalism in U.S.-American Literature and Culture,Seminar,,J,,englisch,2022-04-19,2022-07-19,,"12:00","14:00",Dienstag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Evangelia Kindinger,Seminarraum 1.501,"5. OG ",Dorotheenstraße 24 ,Universitätsgebäude am Hegelplatz,Technische Abteilung (V),"

Sentimentality, today, is understood as an exaggerated and superficial display of emotions, an outdated gesture towards overwhelming feelings of sympathy. Yet in the nineteenth century, based on the assumption that the power of intense emotion creates a &lsquo
column5: character, the sentimental mode was very popular in U.S. fiction, in novels and short stories. Through tales of loss, suffering, moral dilemmas and a loss of innocence, readers of sentimental literature (particularly white and female readers) were instructed in how to be morally infallible. In this course, we will read sentimental literature of the nineteenth century. We will start with the writings of authors such as Walt Whitman, Harriet Jacobs and Susan Warner before turning to expressions of sentimentality in twentieth-century and contemporary media and storytelling: to melodrama, soap operas/telenovelas and reality television.&nbsp

Modernist Poetry,Seminar,https://moodle.hu-berlin.de/enrol/index.php?id=110851,N,,englisch,2022-04-19,2022-07-19,,"08:00","10:00",Dienstag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Stephan Lieske,Seminarraum 1.501,"5. OG ",Dorotheenstraße 24 ,Universitätsgebäude am Hegelplatz,Technische Abteilung (V),"

The class offers a critical interpretation of poetry written before, during, and after World War I as well as contemporary theories of poetry.
column2: On the one hand, we will explore what constitutes its &ldquo
column4: innovations and, on the other, trace relations to the Romantic and Victorian heritage.&nbsp
column5:
The seminar will focus on the poetry of 3 canonical modernist poets: W.B. Yeats, T.S. Eliot, and Ezra Pound. In order to investigate the variety of the poetry of that period we will also study a selection of texts by D.H. Lawrence, Siegfried Sassoon, Wilfred Owen, and others.

"

Kolloquium Psycholinguistik,Kolloquium,,N,,deutsch-englisch,,,,"16:00","18:00",Dienstag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Pia Knoeferle,Seminarraum 3.103,"1. OG ",Dorotheenstraße 24 ,Universitätsgebäude am Hegelplatz,Technische Abteilung (V),"

The colloquium has a focus on research in psycholinguistics. Initial classes will focus on conveying know-how related to conducting research (e.g., a very brief introduction to Latex, forms and protocols, ethics in research, or how to prepare for an interview are example topics). Based on oral presentations and discussion, colloquium participants will gain insight into methods employed in investigating language processing and language learning. The language of instruction is English.

"

Research Practice,Übung,,N,,englisch,2022-04-20,2022-07-20,,"12:00","14:00",Mittwoch,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Elahe Haschemi Yekani,Seminarraum 1.501,"5. OG ",Dorotheenstraße 24 ,Universitätsgebäude am Hegelplatz,Technische Abteilung (V),"

The course aims at practicing and rehearsing research skills central for producing scholarly texts, specifically final theses. It will focus on topics such as identifying a topic and a central research question, structuring the text, and language use. Discussions in class will address questions of methodology, theoretical grounding, academic language, and bibliographic conventions. Students will present their own (preliminary) research projects and draft tables of content, bibliographies, and short sections of text, which will be reviewed by the instructor to facilitate the writing process. The class is most effective for those students who are about to start thinking about and writing their BA thesis
column2: each student needs an academic writing project to make most of this class.&nbsp

column1:
Credit for the course requires regular attendance and participation in class discussions, the completion of the written assignments, and an oral presentation of one's project.

"

Topics in Diachronic Linguistics,Seminar,,N,,englisch,2022-04-19,2022-07-19,,"14:00","16:00",Dienstag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Andrew McIntyre,Hörsaal 3075,"2. OG ",Unter den Linden 6 ,Universitäts-Hauptgebäude,Technische Abteilung (V),"

The course focusses on selected areas in historical syntax, semantics, pragmatics, morphology and phonology. We mainly focus on aspects of the history of English and its ancestors, but we will sometimes examine material from other languages and insights that researchers have gained in working towards a better theory of how and why languages change.
column2:
Examples of subjects covered include grammaticalization (the development of lexical elements into grammatical elements), word order change, passivization, negation, information structure, the semantics and syntax of auxiliaries, general principles of semantic change, the origins of affixes and the reasons for sound change. The topics discussed are selected because of what they reveal about the general nature of language change and/or the English language. Students can attend this course without having attended the accompanying seminar, but should have a rough understanding of the history of English and its earlier ancestor languages, as could be obtained from an encyclopedia article on the subject. It would be useful if attendees have some understanding of basic notions from syntax, morphology and phonology/phonetics, like those taught in introductory courses in our institute.

"

column1:
Case Studies in Economic Criticism,Seminar,,J,,englisch,2022-04-19,2022-07-19,,"12:00","14:00",Dienstag,"14tgl.","14tgl.",Anne Enderwitz,Seminarraum 1.601,"6. OG ",Dorotheenstraße 24 ,Universitätsgebäude am Hegelplatz,Technische Abteilung (V),"

The course offers an introduction to economic criticism. We will read works from different centuries, beginning with Shakespeare&rsquo
column2: s Merchant of Venice, and Defoe&rsquo
column3: s Robinson Crusoe. We will also include a Victorian work that focuses on industrialization (e.g. Elizabeth Gaskell&rsquo
column4: s North and South) and a more contemporary text and film that deal with the recent financial crisis. The course seeks to develop a sense of how literature represents and relates to economic problems and its own material conditions and how it responds to economic crises. We will discuss ideas as well as formal innovations to trace diverse ways in which literature and economics interact.

column1: If you would like to prepare for this course, please being by reading Shakespeare&rsquo
column2: s The Merchant of Venice. We will use the following edition:

column1: Shakespeare, William. The Merchant of Venice, ed. by J. Drakakis, Shakespeare Arden, 2011.

Contrastive Language Analysis: Academic Texts in Contrast,Übung,,N,,englisch,2022-04-19,2022-07-19,,"12:00","14:00",Dienstag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Elisabeth Gibbels,Seminarraum 1.502,"5. OG ",Dorotheenstraße 24 ,Universitätsgebäude am Hegelplatz,Technische Abteilung (V),"

The course will look at differences between German and English academic texts. We will contrast key differences in grammar, style and usage, focusing on typical problem fields for non-English writers and analyse characteristic text features in English academic prose. Coursework will focus on texts from the field of English and American studies. Students will produce translations and summary translations and work with online workshops, peer reviews and editing techniques. Blended course.
Please register by 1 April 2022 using

Social Hydrology,Seminar/Hauptseminar,,J,,englisch,2022-04-19,2022-07-19,,"09:00","13:00",Dienstag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Dieter Gerten,Seminarraum 1.201,"1. OG ",Rudower Chaussee 16 ,Alfred-Rühl-Haus,Technische Abteilung (V),"

The emerging field of socio-hydrology deals with the fact that human activities and the water cycle constantly interact, at an increasingly global scale. This interdisciplinary Study Project (SPJ) aims to clarify and discuss some relevant aspects of human&ndash
column2: water relationships by a set of individual projects/analyses. It combines short lectures, group discussions, practical exercises (ideally data analyses) and several short presentations and reports by students.

column1: In the lecture parts, participants get an introduction into the overall topic of socio-hydrology and specific fields relevant for the study projects to be conducted. Thereby they are guided on how to develop an own research idea and project to be conducted throughout the semester.

In the exercise/work parts, students co-design (mentored by the lecturer) their own focus study, discuss their plan in the plenary, perform the required data analysis and/or literature review, and finally present the main results. Topics and analysis tools for individual projects will be identified during the course depending on the students&rsquo
column2: individual backgrounds and skills. A tentative overall topic are the features of water scarcity in different regions of the world.

column1:
Please register in AGNES, but participation will be agreed on in the first session (April 19). The actual study projects (individually or in teams of two students) will be assigned in the first weeks, following a structured semester schedule.

"

Lecture Series New Faces of Authoritarianism: Interdisciplinary Perspectives from the Global South (ÜWP),Ringvorlesung,,N,,englisch,,,,"14:00","16:00",Donnerstag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Latife Akyüz,Seminarraum 003,EG ,Universitätsstraße 3b ,Institutsgebäude,Technische Abteilung (V),"

The International Research Group on Authoritarianism and Counter-Strategies (IRGAC) is an initiative of the Rosa Luxemburg Foundation that brings together scholar-activists from across the Global South to share and exchange ongoing research on the rise of the Rights and Far-rights and strategic responses from a left-wing perspective. Thus, IRGAC seeks to combine in-depth studies of national and regional processes with a global perspective that recognizes and analyses the multiple manifestations of authoritarian neoliberalism and the different processes that lie beyond the &ldquo

This lecture series aims to provide a space to think and discuss phenomena related to the emergence of authoritarian governments, movements, and ideologies in the countries of the Global South from the different lines of research of the IRGAC members. The course will cover a wide range of central topics to the social sciences today including state violence, biopolitical reproduction of capitalism, sexual dissidence and feminist struggles, the entanglement of authoritarianism with digital technologies, peasant and indigenous movements, the human rights regime, environmental crisis, and gentrification processes. Each of these topics will be articulated addressing the common dynamics and diverse forms of the authoritarian response to the global crisis of neoliberalism. Furthermore, the lecture series will examine the possibilities for alternatives, examples of resistance, and counter-strategies from the Global South.

"

Network based energy systems,Vorlesung/Übung,,N,,englisch,,,,"16:00","20:00",Montag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Franz Hubert,Hörsaal 220,"2. OG ",Spandauer Straße 1 ,Institutsgebäude,Technische Abteilung (V),"

The lecture familiarizes students with the basic notions and tools of the analysis of energy markets and strategic behavior in these markets with an emphasis on electric power and gas. The lecture is accompanied by a tutorial.

Preconditions: A good background in microeconomics, industrial organization and game theory

Oral Skills: Debating,Übung,,N,,englisch,2022-04-19,2022-07-19,,"16:00","18:00",Dienstag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Eimear Kelly,Sprachlabor 325,"3. OG ",Dorotheenstraße 65 ,Boeckh-Haus,Zentraleinrichtung Sprachenzentrum,"

The main focus of this course is on developing debating techniques such as the formulation of convincing arguments under pressure and the analysis of competing ideas. In order to do this, we will examine various political debates held in the UK, Ireland and the USA. A further aspect of the course is the improvement of public speaking skills in general and we shall do this by analysing the rhetorical techniques used in the delivery of inspiring speeches given by Barack Obama, Steve Jobs and Emma Watson amongst others. Students are required to participate in a number of class debates on a variety of contemporary controversial issues.
Please register by 1 April 2022 using
Exchange students only: Please register by 7 April 2022 (4 pm)

Judiciary and Democratic Erosion (ÜWP),Seminar,,N,,englisch,,,,"16:00","18:00",Dienstag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Gülcin Coskun,Seminarraum 003,EG ,Universitätsstraße 3b ,Institutsgebäude,Technische Abteilung (V),"

The millenium is witnessing a global decline of democracy. One of the most important aspect of this democratic erosion is the aggrandizement of the executive and its attacks against horizontal accountability mechanisms including the judiciary. However, at the same time,
column2: the elected antidemocratic leaders need courts to secure their legality and their legitimacy. The emphasis in this course would be on the place and the role of the courts in countries facing a democratic erosion. &nbsp
column3:
This course will introduce students to theoretical debates on this topic as well as to concepts such as judicial purge, court packing or rhetorical attacks against the judiciary.

"

column1:
Advanced Data Analytics for Management Support,Übung,,N,,englisch,,,,"12:00","14:00",Freitag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Victor Medina Olivares,Seminarraum 22,EG ,Spandauer Straße 1 ,Institutsgebäude,Technische Abteilung (V),"

The module Advanced Data Analytics for Management Support (ADAMS) introduces students to the latest developments in the scope of data-driven management support. It covers relevant theories and concepts in machine learning against the background of concrete real-world applications in management science. Special emphasize is given to the analysis of textual data and other forms of complex data such as sequences or images. Corresponding data is typically approached using the framework of deep artificial neural networks. The module recognizes the importance of deep learning and elaborates on corresponding methodologies. Frameworks and practices to use advanced (deep) machine learning technology and deploy corresponding solutions are of critical importance and will be elaborated in tutorial sessions.
The topics covered in the module include but are not limited to:
<ul>
• Fundamentals of artificial neural networks
• Recurrent and convolutional neural networks for sequential data processing
• Fundamentals of natural language processing(NLP)
• Text embedding and language models
• Sentiment Analysis
• Approaches for NLP transfer learning

The module is designed as a follow-up to the module Business Analytics and Data Science (BADS). We expect students to have completed that module prior to taking ADAMS. More specifically, it is strongly recommended to join this module with a solid understanding of (supervised) machine learning practices and algorithms. Some experience in Python programming is also expected since we use the Python programming language in tutorials. The grading of the module will be based on a practical assignment, which also involves Python programming.

"

Policing and Social Structure (ÜWP),Seminar,,N,,englisch,,,,"14:00","16:00",Dienstag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Jeremie Gauthier,Seminarraum 002,EG ,Universitätsstraße 3b ,Institutsgebäude,Technische Abteilung (V),"

The police have become an object of international mobilizations following the murder of George Floyd by a white police officer in Minneapolis in May 2020. This event echoes older concerns in France and Germany about police brutality and racism, as well as the relationship between the police and the urban lower classes. On this topic, the body of literature in the field of the sociology of the police is vast and contributes to question the Weberian definition of the State as ""holder of the monopoly of legitimate violence"" as well the belief on the legitimacy of the authority of criminal institutions.

This seminar aims to highlight a dimension neglected by the current sociology of social control's institutions: How to theoretically investigate the articulation between policing and the social structure? To what extent does the position of individuals in the social structure (class, gender, race etc.) determine their concrete relations with the police as well as their perceptions of the latter? To which extend can empirical quantitative and qualitative research help to analyze the specific relationships with the police according to social groups? By answering these questions, the seminar investigates the proximity and distance, compliance and resistance of individuals toward the police as well as toward the authority of the state.
While exploring research from France, Germany, the United-Kingdom and the United States, the seminar&rsquo
column2:
s goal is to produce a state of art of the existing literature on this matter, to highlight the strengths and weaknesses of the existing theoretical frameworks and to suggest directions for further research.

"

column1:
Culture and Media: Animals in the North American Imagination,Seminar,,J,,englisch,2022-04-20,2022-07-20,,"18:00","20:00",Mittwoch,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Amina Grunewald,Seminarraum 1.501,"5. OG ",Dorotheenstraße 24 ,Universitätsgebäude am Hegelplatz,Technische Abteilung (V),"

The post-human turn and critical reassessment of the Anthropocene (e.g. Singer, 1975, Gruen, 2011, 2015, Haraway, 2016, Cudworth and Hobden, 2018, Braidotti, 2019) have promoted the development of Human Animal Studies, Critical Animal Studies, and the field of Ecocriticism in North American Studies in Germany (Gersdorf 2019, Mauch 2019, Moss, 2020, Tischleder 2019, Zapf 2021 et al.) for the last decade(s). In the Anthropocene / Capitalocene, humanity's impact has put quite a stress on various ecosystems and structural human animal interrelations characterized by contact, cohabitation, conflict, opposition, consumption, and pandemics. For example, human citizens share their lives with companion animals, are entertained by multimedia animal representations, accept &ldquo
column3: animals as commodities in a highly industrialized meat market sector, and are repeatedly confronted with forms of animal - human transmitted diseases.

column1: In addition, the strategy of dehumanizing othering is a tactic of human exceptionalism to establish superiority and obtain power over the Other (human or non-human). Thus, Human Animal Studies and Critical Animal Studies intersect with (Post-)Colonial Studies, Settler Colonial Studies, Feminist Studies, and Gender Studies when focusing on issues of Othering through hegemonic perceptions and supremacist constructions by employing cultural categories such as class, gender, race/ethnicity, abledness, and species.
This seminar discusses North American cultural productions thematizing human animal interrelations in a multispecies world. Questions will be tackled as how the selected works produce a status quo,
column2: offer alternative modes of multispecies co-existence, or how these narratives propagate or eschew post-humanist /post-anthropocentric thinking. Be prepared for strong imagery during some sessions.

column1: Information regarding course requirements and schedule will be provided for registered students during the first session. All seminar texts will be provided on Moodle. Please register for this seminar via AGNES.

Culture and Media: Animals in the North American Imagination,Seminar,,J,,englisch,2022-04-20,2022-07-20,,"18:00","20:00",Mittwoch,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Amina Grunewald,Seminarraum 1.501,"5. OG ",Dorotheenstraße 24 ,Universitätsgebäude am Hegelplatz,Technische Abteilung (V),"

The post-human turn and critical reassessment of the Anthropocene (e.g. Singer, 1975, Gruen, 2011, 2015, Haraway, 2016, Cudworth and Hobden, 2018, Braidotti, 2019) have promoted the development of Human Animal Studies, Critical Animal Studies, and the field of Ecocriticism in North American Studies in Germany (Gersdorf 2019, Mauch 2019, Moss, 2020, Tischleder 2019, Zapf 2021 et al.) for the last decade(s). In the Anthropocene / Capitalocene, humanity's impact has put quite a stress on various ecosystems and structural human animal interrelations characterized by contact, cohabitation, conflict, opposition, consumption, and pandemics. For example, human citizens share their lives with companion animals, are entertained by multimedia animal representations, accept &ldquo
column3: animals as commodities in a highly industrialized meat market sector, and are repeatedly confronted with forms of animal - human transmitted diseases.

column1: In addition, the strategy of dehumanizing othering is a tactic of human exceptionalism to establish superiority and obtain power over the Other (human or non-human). Thus, Human Animal Studies and Critical Animal Studies intersect with (Post-)Colonial Studies, Settler Colonial Studies, Feminist Studies, and Gender Studies when focusing on issues of Othering through hegemonic perceptions and supremacist constructions by employing cultural categories such as class, gender, race/ethnicity, abledness, and species.
This seminar discusses North American cultural productions thematizing human animal interrelations in a multispecies world. Questions will be tackled as how the selected works produce a status quo,
column2: offer alternative modes of multispecies co-existence, or how these narratives propagate or eschew post-humanist /post-anthropocentric thinking. Be prepared for strong imagery during some sessions.

Shakespeares Tragedies,Seminar,,J,,englisch,2022-04-20,2022-07-20,,"12:00","14:00",Mittwoch,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Anne Enderwitz,Hörsaal 1072,EG ,Unter den Linden 6 ,Universitäts-Hauptgebäude,Technische Abteilung (V),"

The seminar offers an introduction to early modern theatre. We will read some of Shakespeare&rsquo
column2: s tragedies together, but we will also look in detail at the material conditions of playacting around 1600 and at social problems that inform early modern plays: gender relations, questions of government, global trade, the significance of reputation in a culture of credit, etc. Looking at early modern theatre opens up an avenue into the past, but it also offers an introduction to plays that are still strikingly relevant today and staged all over the world.

column1: If you want to prepare for this class, begin by reading Othello. We will decide on the other plays in the beginning of the term.
We will work with the Arden editions of Shakespeare&rsquo

The Sonnet in English Literature (Part I and Part II),Seminar,https://moodle.hu-berlin.de/enrol/index.php?id=110850,N,,englisch,2022-04-25,2022-07-18,,"12:00","14:00",Montag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Stephan Lieske,Seminarraum 1.601,"6. OG ",Dorotheenstraße 24 ,Universitätsgebäude am Hegelplatz,Technische Abteilung (V),"

The sonnet has remained one of the most productive poetic forms since the early modern period - in spite of or perhaps because of the manifold modifications of its original ideational and formal structure. The seminar explores the origin of this poetic form in the context of early modern culture and traces the history of sonneteering since then.

The Interwar Years: Democracy, Politics and Gender,Seminar,,J,,englisch,2022-04-25,2022-07-18,,"14:00","16:00",Montag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Eveline Kilian,Hörsaal 1072,EG ,Unter den Linden 6 ,Universitäts-Hauptgebäude,Technische Abteilung (V),"

The years between the two World Wars are a politically fraught era spanning the whole spectrum from fascism to communism. These decades provide an ideal testing ground for an investigation of the manifold interdependencies between democracy, politics and social inequalities. Our focus will be on gender politics and gender norms as well as their intersections with e.g. class, sexuality or ethnicity. For our discussion of issues such as marriage, homosexuality, citizenship and political participation, work or visions of the future, we will rely on both non-fictional material (life writing, journalism, essays) and fictional texts (novels) that will further allow us to reflect on the relationship between politics and aesthetics.
Structure of the module: While the seminar sessions will be conducted on a weekly basis to discuss our reading, the Lektü
column2: rekurs is more project-oriented and will be linked to an international and interdisciplinary autumn school on the Social and Cultural Dimensions of Democracy to take place later in 2022 (probably in the second half of September). The autumn school will be held as part of the European University Alliance Circle U. that links the HU Berlin with eight other European universities. It will not only give participants the opportunity to present and discuss their literature-based projects but also to team up with peers from across Europe, to expand their knowledge beyond the cultural and literary framework of Britain and to learn from adjacent disciplines like history or political science.

column1: Please read the texts listed below as soon as possible. Further material will be made available at the beginning of the semester.

Middle English,Seminar,,N,,englisch,2022-04-19,2022-07-19,,"10:00","12:00",Dienstag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Markus Egg,Hörsaal 3075,"2. OG ",Unter den Linden 6 ,Universitäts-Hauptgebäude,Technische Abteilung (V),"

This class intends to familiarise students with Middle English texts. These texts were written between the Norman Conquest and the Renaissance. We will start with a general introduction into the relevant historical, cultural, and social contexts before tackling the key characteristics of the English of post-conquest Britain. We will review Middle English on different linguistic levels, with the goal to equip students with the necessary skills to read the texts in the original. The set texts are excerpts of canonical texts from different stages of Middle English and various genres.

"

Students will develop a writing portfolio and participate in writing workshops and critiques. This is a blended learning course and will primarily meet in person. Number of participants is limited to 16. Register by e-mail (Lefko003@hotmail.com) to apply for a place in the course. MA American Studies Students only.

Morphology,Seminar,,N,,englisch,2022-04-20,2022-07-20,,"14:00","16:00",Mittwoch,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Florian Schäfer,Hörsaal (Weierstraß) 3038/035,"2. OG ",Unter den Linden 6 ,Universitäts-Hauptgebäude,Technische Abteilung (V),"

This course (note it is a Blockseminar) provides an overview of the principles regulating the internal structure of complex words, focusing on English and how it compares with other languages. We will
column2: learn basic methods of determining this internal structure, and introduce&nbsp
column3: the different strategies that language users may apply in forming new words. In particular, we will discuss processes like&nbsp
column4: derivation, inflection, and compounding, and the rules that govern their application.

Language Awareness: Academic Writing and Critical Thinking,Übung,,N,,englisch,2022-04-22,2022-07-22,,"14:00","16:00",Freitag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,,Seminarraum 1.502,"5. OG ",Dorotheenstraße 24 ,Universitätsgebäude am Hegelplatz,Technische Abteilung (V),"

This course aims to help participants become more confident in critical thinking and writing in English in an academic context. In each session, participants will have the opportunity to read, analyze, and write about several different challenging texts. Vocabulary and grammar appropriate to written academic English will be reviewed in class, with plenty of opportunities to apply it in practice. The course aims to advance participants reading, reasoning, writing, and vocabulary skills. Materials will be provided by the teacher(?).
Please register by 1 April 2022 using this link. [https://moodle.hu-berlin.de/course/view.php?id=73748]
Exchange students: Please register by 7 April 2022 (4 pm) via email to faussera@hu-berlin.de.

Psycholinguistics,Seminar,,N,,englisch,2022-04-20,2022-07-20,,"10:00","12:00",Mittwoch,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Dato Abashidze,Hörsaal 3075,"2. OG ",Unter den Linden 6 ,Universitäts-Hauptgebäude,Technische Abteilung (V),"

This course aims to provide an overview of psycholinguistic research topics and theories. Basic knowledge of experimental tests and statistical analyzes will be presented utilizing the methods of psycholinguistics (such as sentence completion, reaction time and eye-movement measurements). Building on this, research findings and models from selected areas of psycholinguistics, especially sentence and word processing, will be dealt with. Part of the requirement for this course is to design, run and present a small (psycholinguistics) online-experiment.

"

Written Academic Discourse: Writing and Revising the Essay,Übung,,N,,englisch,2022-04-21,2022-07-21,,"12:00","14:00",Donnerstag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Audrey Fausser,PC-Pool 3001,"2. OG ",Unter den Linden 6 ,Universitäts-Hauptgebäude,"Sprach- und literaturwissenschaftliche Fakultät, Institut für Anglistik und Amerikanistik","

This course covers the structural components and conventions of writing in an academic context, with emphasis on the process of writing and extensive revising. The course will guide participants through the process of writing an essay. Peer review activities will aid participants in honing their skills in terms of language use, vocabulary development, register, narrowing a topic, and argumentation. The course will also address conventions of academic writing, for example politically productive and inclusive language. Articles from scholarly journals will provide ample material for students to engage with in further developing their writing skills. Students will compose one essay, which will then undergo several phases of revision.
Please register by 1 April 2022 using
Exchange students: Please register by 7 April 2022 (4 pm)

English Historical Syntax,Seminar,,N,,englisch,2022-04-22,2022-07-22,,"14:00","16:00",Freitag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Florian Schäfer,Hörsaal 2014A,"1. OG ",Unter den Linden 6 ,Universitäts-Hauptgebäude,Technische Abteilung (V),"

This course deals with syntactic change in the history of English (in comparison, in particular, with German and French). Phenomena to be discussed will include the loss of inflectional paradigms, the rise of auxiliaries and modals, the loss of auxiliary selection in the perfect
column2: tense, the change from OV to VO word order, the loss of verb movement&nbsp
column3: and the development of do-support, and the partial loss of the&nbsp
column4:
verb-second constraint. Students should have interest in formal syntactic descriptions.

"

OG ",Unter den Linden 6 ,Universitäts-Hauptgebäude,"Sprach- und literaturwissenschaftliche Fakultät, Institut für Anglistik und Amerikanistik","

This course equips participants to be more effective in discussing topics relevant to English and American Studies, with a specific focus on literary topics. The course will focus on the development of academic vocabulary and employing strategies for more effective oral communication as well as argumentation in academic discussions. Students will identify and prepare relevant topics and perspectives in order to participate in panel discussions. Additional discussion activities will provide course participants opportunities to further develop and practice their oral skills.

Language Awareness: The Language of Literary Studies,Übung,,N,,englisch,2022-04-21,2022-07-21,,"12:00","14:00",Donnerstag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Elisabeth Gibbels,Seminarraum (ehem. 0109) 0007,EG ,Hausvogteiplatz 5-7 ,Institutsgebäude,Technische Abteilung (V),"

This course explores a range of vital literary theory including formalism, Marxism, feminism, New Historicism, queer theory and postcolonialism. The aim is for students to grow to feel at home utilising literary theory in their academic compositions. Students will be given the chance to focus on theory which they find especially interesting and to apply it in their own brief response papers to literary texts. This work will open up opportunities to hone academic practices such as summary, drafting, quotation, and citation. Blended course.

Ecocriticism and the Literatures of the Asian Diaspora (Part I and Part II),Seminar,,N,,englisch,2022-04-21,2022-07-21,,"14:00","16:00",Donnerstag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Selma Bidlingmaier,PC-Pool 3001,"2. OG ",Unter den Linden 6 ,Universitäts-Hauptgebäude,"Sprach- und literaturwissenschaftliche Fakultät, Institut für Anglistik und Amerikanistik","

This course explores the intersections between colonialism, imperialism, the environment as represented in the literary, and cultural works of the Asian diaspora. The goal of this course is to 1) provide an introduction to postcolonial theory and ecocriticism, and 2) to historically situate the literature of the Asian diaspora and immigration within the larger contexts of the Anthropocene. Utilizing concepts such as Alfred Crosby and Richard Grove&rsquo
column4: s slow violence, and Gayatri Chakravorty Spivak&rsquo
column5: s planetarity, we will examine ways of engaging with the literature of the Asian diaspora beyond imperial-colonial logics of androcentric and anthropocentric dualisms. Alongside our theoretical reading, we will examine Amitav Ghosh&rsquo
column6: s The Hungry Tide, Arundhati Roy The God of Small Things, Maxine Hong Kingston&rsquo
column8: s Homebase, and Han Ong The Disinherited, and Karen Tei Yamashita&rsquo
column9:
s Through the Arc of the Rainforest.

"

Ecocriticism and the Literatures of the Asian Diaspora (Part I),Seminar,,N,,englisch,2022-04-21,2022-07-21,,"14:00","16:00",Donnerstag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Selma Bidlingmaier,PC-Pool 3001,"2. OG ",Unter den Linden 6 ,Universitäts-Hauptgebäude,"Sprach- und literaturwissenschaftliche Fakultät, Institut für Anglistik und Amerikanistik","

This course explores the intersections between colonialism, imperialism, the environment as represented in the literary, and cultural works of the Asian diaspora. The goal of this course is to 1) provide an introduction to postcolonial theory and ecocriticism, and 2) to historically situate the literature of the Asian diaspora and immigration within the larger contexts of the Anthropocene. Utilizing concepts such as Alfred Crosby and Richard Grove&rsquo
column4: s slow violence, and Gayatri Chakravorty Spivak&rsquo
column5: s planetarity, we will examine ways of engaging with the literature of the Asian diaspora beyond imperial-colonial logics of androcentric and anthropocentric dualisms. Alongside our theoretical reading, we will examine Amitav Ghosh&rsquo
column6: s The Hungry Tide, Arundhati Roy The God of Small Things, Maxine Hong Kingston&rsquo
column8: s Homebase, and Han Ong The Disinherited, and Karen Tei Yamashita&rsquo
column9:
s Through the Arc of the Rainforest.

OG ",Unter den Linden 6 ,Universitäts-Hauptgebäude,"Sprach- und literaturwissenschaftliche Fakultät, Institut für Anglistik und Amerikanistik","

This course focuses on significant contemporary issues concerning education, civil liberties, and political and social developments in the U.S. Participants will complete readings at home, take part in discussions, and write short essays on the topics addressed in the course. Number of participants limited to 16. Register by e-mail (faussera@hu-berlin.de) to apply for a place in the course.

"

Introduction to Linguistics,Grundkurs,,N,,englisch,2022-04-21,2022-07-21,,"08:00","10:00",Donnerstag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Markus Egg,Hörsaal 1072,EG ,Unter den Linden 6 ,Universitäts-Hauptgebäude,Technische Abteilung (V),"

This course introduces five core areas of grammar: Phonetics/phonology investigates the sounds of English and how are they used to distinguish meanings. Morphology describes the structure of words and syntax, with the structure of sentences. Finally, semantics is about the way in which linguistic expressions (in particular, words and sentences) can be interpreted, and pragmatics deals with the way in which language is used to perform concrete actions. The course prepares students for the MAP of Module 1.

"

Pragmatics,Seminar,,N,,englisch,2022-04-20,2022-07-20,,"10:00","12:00",Mittwoch,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Florian Schäfer,Hörsaal 1072,EG ,Unter den Linden 6 ,Universitäts-Hauptgebäude,Technische Abteilung (V),"

This course introduces into the linguistic sub-discipline pragmatics. We examine the relationship between the meaning of an utterance and the context in which the utterance is produced. We will explore a wide range of topics in the discipline, such as presupposition, implicature, speech acts, deixis and reference.

"

Phonetics & Phonology,Seminar,,N,,englisch,2022-04-21,2022-07-21,,"10:00","12:00",Donnerstag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Reginald Duah,Hörsaal 2014A,"1. OG ",Unter den Linden 6 ,Universitäts-Hauptgebäude,Technische Abteilung (V),"

This course introduces students to the mechanisms of the production of speech sounds, e.g. vowels and consonants, their description, classification and transcription. The course will explore how speech sounds are organized across languages. We will practice how to establish speech sounds in a language (or phonemes) by using minimal pairs and complementary distribution. We will learn basic phonological processes which occur in language.

American Film History and Theory,Übung,https://moodle.hu-berlin.de/course/view.php?id=110352,N,,englisch,2022-04-21,2022-07-21,,"10:00","12:00",Donnerstag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Martin Klepper,Seminarraum 1.601,"6. OG ",Dorotheenstraße 24 ,Universitätsgebäude am Hegelplatz,Technische Abteilung (V),"

This course is an advanced survey class on a) aspects of American movie history, b) filmic techniques, and c) some seminal texts in film theory. We will look at some of the major steps in the development of American cinema and discuss some seminal movies
column2: we will discuss influential film theories by Walter Benjamin, Jean-Louis Baudry, Laura Mulvey, and Linda Williams as well as some chapters from an introduction into film theory by Thomas Elsaesser and Malte Hagener
column3: and we will have a look at basic filmic techniques such as image and shot, perspective, camera movement, lighting, color and sound, editing, film narratology and semiotics.

This course is designed to explore the British short story from the Victorian period to contemporary short fiction &ndash

column3: Virginia Woolf etc.) to conclude with postcolonial short fiction and recent &lsquo
column7: in the digital media. Apart from tracing a historical line, we shall also look at (bilingual) anthologies catering to teaching. Finally, we shall also reflect on issues of genre theory and pertinent methodologies of critical reading (&lsquo

This course is designed to give future teachers practice using English on the job &ndash
column2: before they find themselves in charge of a class! Participants will practice designing classroom activities for different learner proficiency levels in speaking, listening, reading, and writing, and familiarizing themselves with students&rsquo
column3: oral and written abilities at each level - all in English. Special attention will be paid to appropriate classroom vocabulary and making activities interesting and effective. This is a blended learning course and will primarily meet in person. MA Education students only.

column2:
s utterances into another language) with a particular focus on interpreting speeches. Students will work on relevant skills such as oral expression, public speaking, analysing speech structures and note-taking. Discourse Structure and Processing,Seminar,,N,,englisch,2022-04-19,2022-07-19,,"10:00","12:00",Dienstag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Debopam Das,Seminarraum 2004A,"1. OG ",Unter den Linden 6 ,Universitäts-Hauptgebäude,Technische Abteilung (V),"

This course provides an introduction to how discourse is structured, primarily through discourse coherence and discourse relations, and also to how discourse is processed by humans. Discourse is defined as the language above the level of sentence and also the use of language in context. In this course, we will learn about a wide range of phenomena included in the study of discourse structure and discourse processing from linguistic and psycholinguistic points of view. Students will read original and recent work in these areas. They will also examine different forms of discourse and analyze important aspects of discourse processing. The students will be evaluated based on their performance in a number of activities, such as writing summaries and reviews, and writing (and presenting) a short term-paper.

"

This course provides an overview of the principles regulating the internal structure of complex words, focusing on English and how it compares with other languages. We will
column2: learn basic methods of determining this internal structure, and introduce&nbsp
column3: the different strategies that language users may apply in forming new words. In particular, we will discuss processes like&nbsp
column4:
derivation, inflection, and compounding, and the rules that govern their application.

Oral Skills: Exploring Culture and Society in the USA,Übung,,N,,englisch,2022-04-19,2022-07-19,,"14:00","16:00",Dienstag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Audrey Fausser,PC-Pool 3001,"2. OG ",Unter den Linden 6 ,Universitäts-Hauptgebäude,"Sprach- und literaturwissenschaftliche Fakultät, Institut für Anglistik und Amerikanistik","

This course provides students the opportunity to explore current culturally relevant issues in the United States. Course participants will determine the foci of the topics covered and address them in argumentative/persuasive presentations: entertainment, the fine and performing arts, free speech, race/ethnicity, and national holidays and national identity. Additional discussion activities will address the intersection of the course topics and cultural appropriation, intersectionality, privilege, and income disparity. Course activities will provide students with ample material to strengthen their discussion skills, to further develop their presentation and language skills, as well as to expand their knowledge on current culturally relevant topics in the context of the US.
Please register by 1 April 2022 using
Exchange students: Please register by 7 April 2022 (4 pm)

Oral Skills: Considering People and Politics in the USA,Übung,,N,,englisch,2022-04-22,2022-07-22,,"10:00","12:00",Freitag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Audrey Fausser,PC-Pool 3001,"2. OG ",Unter den Linden 6 ,Universitäts-Hauptgebäude,"Sprach- und literaturwissenschaftliche Fakultät, Institut für Anglistik und Amerikanistik","

This course provides students the opportunity to explore the divisive issues currently being debated in the USA. Through exposure to a variety of media outlets, students will gain a better understanding of how the United States sees itself and how politically and socially relevant issues intersect. Course participants will determine the foci of the major course topics covered (e.g. the media, immigration, women&rsquo
column2: s and LBGTQIA+ rights) and address them in informative presentations. In addition, participants will individually explore the broader course topics within a particular state. Both activities will provide students with ample material to strengthen their discussion skills, to further develop their presentation and language skills, as well as to expand their knowledge on the current issues, both at the national and state levels.
