Oral Skills: Presentation Practice,Übung,,N,,englisch,2022-04-22,2022-07-22,,"14:00","16:00",Freitag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,,Seminarraum 1.501,"5. OG ",Dorotheenstraße 24 ,Universitätsgebäude am Hegelplatz,Technische Abteilung (V),"

This course provides students the opportunity to focus on the skills necessary to deliver an effective presentation in an academic context. A persuasive/argumentative presentation on a literary topic as well as peer evaluation will enable participants to practice their skills in terms of topic development, structure and organization, content, and delivery, in addition to further developing their language skills (e.g. vocabulary development, language formality, etc.).
Please register by 1 April 2022 using

Written Academic Discourse: Writing Academic Essays,Übung,,N,,englisch,2022-04-22,2022-07-22,,"12:00","14:00",Freitag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Audrey Fausser,PC-Pool 3001,"2. OG ",Unter den Linden 6 ,Universitäts-Hauptgebäude,"Sprach- und literaturwissenschaftliche Fakultät, Institut für Anglistik und Amerikanistik","

This course provides students the opportunity to identify, analyze, and practice a variety of skills necessary for writing in academia. The course will guide participants through the process of writing an essay. Peer review activities will aid participants in honing their skills in terms of language use, vocabulary development, register, narrowing a topic, and argumentation. The course will also address conventions of academic writing, for example politically productive and inclusive language. Articles from scholarly journals will provide ample material for students to engage with in further developing their writing skills. Students will compose two short argumentative essays in this course.
Please register by 1 April 2022 using
Exchange students: Please register by 7 April 2022 (4 pm)

Language Change,Seminar,,N,,englisch,2022-04-19,2022-07-19,,"12:00","14:00",Dienstag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Artemis Alexiadou,Hörsaal 2014B,"1. OG ",Unter den Linden 6 ,Universitäts-Hauptgebäude,Technische Abteilung (V),"

This course will examine how languages change over time, with a focus on changes at the levels of phonology, morphology and syntax. In addition to a descriptive overview of common types of change and a theoretical investigation of the various mechanisms that cause and constrain the changes, we will devote significant time to methodological discussions about how we collect and interpret historical language data to arrive at an understanding of linguistic systems that are no longer spoken and identify the changes that have affected them.

"

The grammar of code switching,Seminar,,J,,englisch,2022-04-19,2022-07-19,,"10:00","12:00",Dienstag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Artemis Alexiadou,Hörsaal 2014B,"1. OG ",Unter den Linden 6 ,Universitäts-Hauptgebäude,Technische Abteilung (V),"

This course will focus on linguistic aspects of code-switching, defined as the mixing of elements from two or more languages of a bilingual speaker within a sentence or a word. We will examine the principles that underlie code-switching, by looking at a variety of grammatical phenomena from several mixing varieties.

"

This course will focus on linguistic aspects of code-switching, defined as the mixing of elements from two or more languages of a bilingual speaker within a sentence or a word. We will examine the principles that underlie code-switching, by looking at a variety of grammatical phenomena from several mixing varieties.

"

Writing the Term Paper,Übung,,N,,englisch,2022-04-19,2022-07-19,,"12:00","14:00",Dienstag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Audrey Fausser,PC-Pool 3001,"2. OG ",Unter den Linden 6 ,Universitäts-Hauptgebäude,"Sprach- und literaturwissenschaftliche Fakultät, Institut für Anglistik und Amerikanistik","

This course will help the students develop the skills needed to write an academic term paper: examining the requirements of a genre, developing a thesis, planning and organization, integrating and documenting secondary literature, close reading, outlining/pre-writing, flow/coherence, academic tone and style, revising for clarity, giving peer feedback, etc. One longer paper will be developed during the course, and there will be writing and organization exercises regularly.
column2: Course only for BA American Studies majors

Semantics,Seminar,,N,,englisch,2022-04-21,2022-07-21,,"14:00","16:00",Donnerstag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Moreno Mitrovi&#263
column2:
,Hörsaal 2002,"1. OG ",Unter den Linden 6 ,Universitäts-Hauptgebäude,Technische Abteilung (V),"

This course will introduce candidates to the formal study of meaning, staring with questions such as What is meaning. An
column3: overarching problem we will meditate on, and try our best to solve, concerns the way in which a meaning of a string of&nbsp
column4: words and sentences are built to mean what they do. Since it is impossible to agree on even the meaning of the word&nbsp
column7: , linguists have adopted a system from logic (the intersection of Mathematics and Philosophy) that can begin to&nbsp
column8: solve this problem. This logical system is what this course is about. This will ultimately lead us to ponder the relationship&nbsp
column9: between grammar and logic. The students will not only learn the logical methods of conducting formal semantic analyses,&nbsp
column10: but will also be introduced to the philosophical issues that underlie them. The course will, to a large extent, follow the&nbsp
column12: Kratzer (""Semantics in Generative Grammar"", Blackwell, 1998), although handouts, slides, and&nbsp
column13:
additional material will be provided. The assessment will be continuous and will take shape of on-going problem sets and a final exam (MAP).

"

This course will look at a selection of short texts from the field of Cultural Studies, both in the British and the American academic environment. Students will increase their own awareness of the language used in cultural studies, expand their vocabulary and become familiar with differences between everyday language use and academic discourse. Several language exercises and brief writing assignments will help students write confidently and correctly on issues in Cultural Studies. Blended course.

Introduction to Cultural Studies and Theory,Seminar,,N,,englisch,2022-04-19,2022-07-19,,"14:00","16:00",Dienstag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Charlotte Alex,Hörsaal 1072,EG ,Unter den Linden 6 ,Universitäts-Hauptgebäude,Technische Abteilung (V),"

This course will provide an introduction to the basics of Cultural Studies: concepts of culture, models of cultural exchange, ways of &lsquo
column3: culture and cultural artefacts (especially film analysis), concepts of history and of cultural memory, issues of Gender Studies and of Postcolonial Studies will be examined and discussed using selected examples from literature and popular culture. A reader with material will be provided at the beginning of the class.

column1:
Culture and Context: Topics in American History,Seminar,,N,,englisch,2022-04-19,2022-07-19,,"14:00","16:00",Dienstag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Eva Boesenberg,Seminarraum 1.501,"5. OG ",Dorotheenstraße 24 ,Universitätsgebäude am Hegelplatz,Technische Abteilung (V),"

This course will take a closer look at some of the historical developments that have shaped North American literature and culture, and have been shaped by them in turn. It will also address the question of how an understanding of history is informed by one's standpoint as well as social hierarchies more generally. Some of the topics we will discuss include the ongoing significance of settler colonialism
column4: the constitution of the United States
column8: the Civil Rights Movement, Indigenous rights movements, the Black Lives Matter movement
column9:
and the historical roots of the Trump presidency. The course will foreground an understanding of ongoing historiographical debates and methods of interpreting primary sources.

"

column1:
English Historical Linguistics and Dialectology,Seminar,,N,,englisch,2022-04-19,2022-07-19,,"16:00","18:00",Dienstag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Andrew McIntyre,Hörsaal (Weierstraß) 3038/035,"2. OG ",Unter den Linden 6 ,Universitäts-Hauptgebäude,Technische Abteilung (V),"

This introductory seminar gives a survey of historical change in phonology, morphology/syntax and the lexicon across the Old, Middle and (Early/Late) Modern English periods to the present day as well as of current geographical and socio-functional variation in the English language. It thus emphasizes the close relationship between language change and variation. It introduces the concept of the sociolinguistic situation with its various parameters and presents language change and variation as complex processes determined by the interaction of language-internal forces and extralinguistic factors. It sets the framework for a more detailed treatment of historical language change or, alternatively, of contemporary variation of the English language in the UEs offered in this module.

"

This research and writing course is designed for BA-students in their final semesters. It is designed to prepare and support BA-thesis candidates in writing their BA-thesis.
We will cover topics such as: How to plan and organise your BA-thesis-project
column2: how to find an appropriate thesis topic and a central research question
column3: how to come up with a first outline and structure of your thesis. Furthermore, we will talk about bibliographical conventions, the use of academic language, about methodology, theoretical grounding and contextualisation of your topics.

column1: In this class we will run through the process of writing an academic paper &ndash

column3: each student needs an academic writing project to make most of this class.

This seminar aims to give participants a good understanding of a broad range of issues in syntax. After revising the material covered in the introductory courses, the course will cover (among other things) functional categories (determiners, auxiliaries and complementizers), passive, question formation, infinitives, negation and relative clauses.

column1:
Performing the East in Early Modern Drama,Seminar,,N,,englisch,2022-04-25,2022-07-18,,"10:00","12:00",Montag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Katrin Röder,Seminarraum 1.501,"5. OG ",Dorotheenstraße 24 ,Universitätsgebäude am Hegelplatz,Technische Abteilung (V),"

This seminar explores late sixteenth- and early seventeenth-century dramatic depictions and performances of male and female characters and settings from the East, a cultural and imaginative space which held great fascination for early modern dramatists and theatre audiences, comprising regions from the Eastern Mediterranean and Africa to East Asia. According to contemporary scholars, early modern English representations of the East and especially of Muslims and Islamic cultures were more ambiguous and fluid than in the period of Orientalism in the 18th
column3: centuries: they were tendentious, hateful, often polemic and sometimes favourable, characterised by a blend of fear, admiration, desire and imperial envy. Early modern drama contains stereotypical images and characters that still influence Western perspectives on the East (especially Islam), e. g. the cruel, aggressive or voluptuous male Turk/Muslim or the seductive (and in the case of Early modern drama strikingly powerful) woman of the East. This seminar will examine if the selected dramatic texts can be said to belong to a period &ldquo
column5:
(as some scholars have suggested), not merely in historical but also in cultural and aesthetic terms. We will focus on the following questions: do early modern plays imagine the East in ways that cannot not be reduced to Orientalist binary oppositions between the culturally and morally superior West and the inferior East? Do the selected texts reproduce, endorse or even challenge or unsettle such oppositions and strategies of Othering? What is the role of dramatic performance in representations of cultural and gender identities in the plays, e. g. in the contexts of religious conversions and intercultural love relationships?

"

Motor control of daily-life locomotion,Seminar,,N,,englisch,2022-04-25,2022-07-22,,"12:15","13:45",Montag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Alessandro Santuz,Seminarraum 2 0.05,EG ,Hannoversche Straße 27 ,Haus 25 / Bürogebäude,"Kultur-, Sozial- und Bildungswissenschaftliche Fakultät, Institut für Sportwissenschaft","

This seminar will be held in English language. Main focus will be on the muscle coordination strategies used by the central nervous system to organise locomotor activity such as walking and running. In particular, we will consider real-world or ecological settings (i.e., out of the lab) and talk about how perturbations are constantly part of daily-life locomotion and why is somatosensory feedback crucial to robustly control movement. The use of artificial perturbations to simulate real-world settings will be explained in depth, with particular attention on how scientists can leverage perturbations to uncover fundamental mechanisms for the neural control of locomotion.

"

Language Awareness: Humour in British Culture,Übung,,N,,englisch,2022-04-25,2022-07-18,,"10:00","12:00",Montag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Dave Ball,Seminarraum 2004A,"1. OG ",Unter den Linden 6 ,Universitäts-Hauptgebäude,Technische Abteilung (V),"

Using examples taken from literature, art, television, stand-up comedy, and everyday discourse, this course explores the use of humour in British culture. A defining characteristic of Britishness, the use of humour will be examined in a range of contexts, with a focus on literary and comic deployments of irony, satire, farce, surrealism, and incongruity. The course develops students&rsquo
column2: ability to understand, describe, and analyse particular examples of humour, along with opportunities to practice their analytic writing skills.

Self-Optimization and Self-Management,Seminar,https://moodle.hu-berlin.de/course/view.php?id=110353,N,,englisch,2022-04-20,2022-07-20,,"16:00","18:00",Mittwoch,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Martin Klepper,Seminarraum 1.601,"6. OG ",Dorotheenstraße 24 ,Universitätsgebäude am Hegelplatz,Technische Abteilung (V),"

Very likely, you will find a course, seminar or workshop like this in Schools of Business Administration, Continued Education units for managers and self-employed entrepreneurs or Advanced Training offers for occupational psychologists. The difference between those classes and this one is that they mean it: they want to pass on skills for self-optimization or self-management. In contrast, what I want to do in this class is to critically observe the phenomenon. Since Frederick Winslow Taylor (The Principles of Scientific Management), Dale Carnegie (How to win friends and influence people) and Napoleon Hill (Think and Grow Rich) ideas of self-optimization and self-management have become a hallmark of normative workplace mentality in the United States. Even before this (think of Benjamin Franklin, Ralph Waldo Emerson) work on the self was a part of the American self-definition. In this seminar, we will explore and analyze the ideas of self-optimization and self-management, describe their objectives, ideological underpinnings, features and strategies and try to be aware of differences in race and gender and what they do not do. Subsequently, we will (in the form of group projects) study individual self-optimization or self-management tools (in books, films, the internet, Instagram or YouTube) and relate their assertions and methods to the critical thinking and critical apparatus we have until then, hopefully, assembled.

"

The Power of Words/Critical Discourse Analysis,Seminar,,N,,englisch,2022-04-21,2022-07-20,,"10:00","12:00",Donnerstag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Marit Vos,Übungsraum 0122-23,"1. OG ",Hausvogteiplatz 5-7 ,Institutsgebäude,"Sprach- und literaturwissenschaftliche Fakultät, Institut für Anglistik und Amerikanistik","

We live in exiting times: the pandemic situation changes every week, there are many political events all over the world that have an impact on our lives, or look at topics like climate change that keep us busy every day. The way we experience these big and important topics is through language. Language, though, is never objective, words are not neutral and we are constantly being (mis)led by words when we try to develop our own &lsquo

In this seminar, we will work with Critical Discourse Analysis (CDA) and study the language in all kinds of contemporary texts (political speeches, newspaper articles, commercials, comedy shows promotion material from NGOs, statements of public personae, etc.), on topics that are of interest for all participants of this course. We will analyse and compare these texts in the way they use rhetorical features, concepts of framing, etc. and become more aware of which ways are being used to manipulate our ways of thinking. As a future teacher, you will be able to practice and apply the knowledge and techniques you have learned in future high school English classes as well.

Experimental Pragmatics,Seminar,,N,,englisch,2022-04-25,2022-07-18,,"12:00","14:00",Montag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Mingya Liu,Hörsaal 1072,EG ,Unter den Linden 6 ,Universitäts-Hauptgebäude,Technische Abteilung (V),"

Whereas semantics is concerned with the context-independent interpretation of sentences in relation to their subparts, pragmatics is concerned with the context-dependent interpretation of utterances that is related to but goes beyond sentence semantics, as the utterance of the same sentence can invite different - pragmatic - inferences, depending on the utterance situation composed of e.g. the speaker, the addressee, the place, the time. In this class, we will focus on the pragmatic phenomena of presupposition and implicature using experimental methods, aka &ldquo
column3: (i.e. works that aim at promoting interaction between linguistic, psychological, and philosophical&nbsp
column4:
approaches to utterance interpretation). The class will be divided into two parts: In the first part, I will review research on presupposition and implicature as a recap and introduce methods of Experimental Pragmatics (with measures such as ratings, reading times, electroencephalogram/EEG), in the form of lectures. In the second part, we will work through a selection of case studies in the form of students' presentations and general discussions.

"

column1:
Decoloniality in South African Literature,Seminar,,N,,englisch,2022-04-25,2022-07-18,,"14:00","16:00",Montag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Laurel Braddock,Hörsaal 2014A,"1. OG ",Unter den Linden 6 ,Universitäts-Hauptgebäude,Technische Abteilung (V),"

Whilst it has a long and global history, the term 'decoloniality' was brought to the fore by the 2015 South African student movements known as the #RhodesMustFall protests, protests which also gained traction in other academic epicentres such as Oxford University in England. But how is 'decolonial' and 'decoloniality' different from postcolonial studies? What does decoloniality call for, and how is this catalysed in works of literature?

Nearly three decades after the end of apartheid in South Africa, contemporary South African literature simultaneously contends with its history of colonialism and racial segregation, as well as its present of continuing economic disparities. In this course, we look at a selection of South African poetry and speculative fiction. These works grapple with topics of land, sexuality, gender and race
column2: they uncover the lasting effects of colonial, hegemonic and narrow understanding of what it means to be human
column3:
and they fight against the erasure of indigenous systems of knowledge. In doing so, these works of literature participate in and complicate the urgent cultural and political debates on decoloniality.

Indicative reading: Koleka Putuma, _Collective Amnesia

column1:
Modernism and Right-Wing Politics (Part 1 and 2),Seminar,,N,,englisch,2022-04-21,2022-07-21,,"12:00","14:00",Donnerstag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Katrin Frisch,Seminarraum 1.601,"6. OG ",Dorotheenstraße 24 ,Universitätsgebäude am Hegelplatz,Technische Abteilung (V),"

With its stylistic innovations, bold experimental forms and novel ideas, Modernism brought forth a cultural sea change. The poet Ezra Pound encapsulated the transformative power of Modernism in his slogan &sbquo
column5: did not only pertain to art, but also served as a political slogan. More specifically, he used it to promote the Fascist revolution. What at first glance seems like a contradiction &ndash
column6: the Modernist artist in favour of deeply reactionary politics &ndash
column7: is an indicator of a larger pattern. In fact, many prominent Modernist writers embraced right-wing politics, while advocating for a renewal in art.

column1: In this course we will analyse key Modernist texts, starting from early twentieth-century intellectual reactions of the avant-garde against liberal democracy and the burgeoning emancipatory movements to the full-fledged support for continental European fascist regimes by some Modernist authors. Focussing on T.S. Eliot, Ezra Pound, Wyndham Lewis and D. H. Lawrence we will trace the way these writers married right-wing ideology and Modernist literary style. Moreover, the course will throw some light on the way literary criticism has shaped our understanding of the matter. Our literary and cultural analyses will be supported by a robust theoretical framework on right-wing ideology as well as the nature of fascism including reflections on the role of race, class, gender and other categories in anti-democratic thought.

Scientific Writing,Masterseminar,https://moodle.hu-berlin.de/course/view.php?id=110018,N,,englisch,2022-04-21,2022-06-02,,"11:00","13:00",Donnerstag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Julia Boike,Unterrichtsraum 0.101,EG ,Rudower Chaussee 16 ,Alfred-Rühl-Haus,Technische Abteilung (V),"

Writing is central to scientific communication and academic work. This course will introduce you to writing and reviewing scientific articles and theses. We will use a mixture of lectures, individual and group work, and article discussions to understand the DOs and DON'Ts in scientific writing. Foremost, you will learn strategies that are common to both thesis and paper writing, including (i) how to plan, organise and structure your article/thesis, (ii) how to research relevant literature, (iii) how to write different parts of articles/theses, (iv) how to plan and integrate visual items, (v) how to evaluate articles/theses of your peers, (vi) how to identify and avoid plagiarism, and (vii) how to cite correctly. Additionally, we will discuss certain aspects that are specific to writing scientific articles, for example journal aims and scopes, editorial processes. Also, soft skills will be trained and practiced during the course including the preparation/development of own high quality presentations.

In the end, you should be able to communicate your scientific results in a correct, structured and appealing way, for your thesis or academia.

"

Ziel des Seminars ist ein Ü
column3: ber die historische Entwicklung von Medientheorien unter besonderer Ber&uuml
column5: ltnisses zu den Literaturwissenschaften. Dabei soll der Frage nachgegangen werden, wie die mediale Verfasstheit menschlicher Kommunikation in den Vordergrund &auml
column7: ckt ist. Das Seminar ist in drei Bl&ouml
column8: cke unterteilt. Der erste Block untersucht Medientheorien avant la lettre als Wiederkehr alter Fragen der Philosophiegeschichte unter neuen Bedingungen. Hier geht es u.a. um Probleme der Schrift (Platon) und der Wahrnehmung (Kant). Der zweite Block nimmt Medientheorien zu Beginn des 20. Jahrhunderts in den Blick und analysiert den Wandel der kulturtheoretischen Betrachtung kü
column10: nge am Beispiel des Films (Benjamin) und des Radios (Brecht). Der dritte Block untersucht sodann die Entwicklung prominenter Medientheorien nach dem medial turn: Marshall McLuhan, Paul Virilio, Friedrich Kittler.

Zwar ist die Gleichberechtigung der Geschlechter im Grundgesetz festgeschrieben, dennoch finden sich empirisch vielfä
column2: ltige Ungleichheiten zwischen den Geschlechtern. Die Kategorie &bdquo
column4: ist damit (nach wie vor) eine zentrale Kategorie sozialer Ungleichheit. Die aktuelle COVID-19 Pandemie vergr&ouml
column7: hrt zu einem Backlash und einer ungeahnten Retraditionalisierung der Geschlechterverh&auml

column1: Nach einer historischen Einfü
column2: hrung werden im ersten Block des Seminars wesentliche soziologische Theorien und Konzepte zu Geschlechterungleichheiten vorgestellt: Die fr&uuml
column3: he Frauenforschung macht die gesellschaftliche Arbeitsteilung als Ursache der Ungleichheiten zwischen den Geschlechtern aus. Das Konzept der doppelten Vergesellschaftung von Frauen fasst Geschlecht als Strukturkategorie und zeigt Widerspr&uuml
column4: che auf, die sich daraus ergeben. Ein weiterer zentraler Ansatz fasst Geschlecht als sozial konstruiert und in Interaktionen hergestellt (doing gender). Doch Geschlecht l&auml

column1: Der nä
column2: chste Block widmet sich der Trias Arbeit, Staat und Paarbeziehungen. Welchen Einfluss haben Wohlfahrtsstaaten auf Ungleichheiten? Wie wirkt Geschlecht in Prozessen auf dem Arbeitsmarkt und in Organisationen? Und welche Konsequenzen hat dies auf Liebes- und Paarbeziehungen sowie der Vereinbarkeit von Familie und Beruf?

column1: Im dritten Block betrachten wir unterschiedliche gesellschaftliche Felder aus einer geschlechter- und ungleichheitskritischen Perspektive. Wir richten den Blick auf Mä

Einführung in Geschlecht, Arbeit, Ungleichheit (ÜWP),Seminar,,J,,deutsch,,,,"08:00","10:00",Donnerstag,wöchentlich,wöchentlich,Lena Schürmann,Seminarraum 004,EG ,Universitätsstraße 3b ,Institutsgebäude,Technische Abteilung (V),"

Zwar ist die Gleichberechtigung der Geschlechter im Grundgesetz festgeschrieben, dennoch finden sich empirisch vielfä
column2: ltige Ungleichheiten zwischen den Geschlechtern. Die Kategorie &bdquo
column4: ist damit (nach wie vor) eine zentrale Kategorie sozialer Ungleichheit. Die aktuelle COVID-19 Pandemie vergr&ouml
column7: hrt zu einem Backlash und einer ungeahnten Retraditionalisierung der Geschlechterverh&auml

column1: Nach einer historischen Einfü
column2: hrung werden im ersten Block des Seminars wesentliche soziologische Theorien und Konzepte zu Geschlechterungleichheiten vorgestellt: Die fr&uuml
column3: he Frauenforschung macht die gesellschaftliche Arbeitsteilung als Ursache der Ungleichheiten zwischen den Geschlechtern aus. Das Konzept der doppelten Vergesellschaftung von Frauen fasst Geschlecht als Strukturkategorie und zeigt Widerspr&uuml
column4: che auf, die sich daraus ergeben. Ein weiterer zentraler Ansatz fasst Geschlecht als sozial konstruiert und in Interaktionen hergestellt (doing gender). Doch Geschlecht l&auml

column1: Der nä
column2: chste Block widmet sich der Trias Arbeit, Staat und Paarbeziehungen. Welchen Einfluss haben Wohlfahrtsstaaten auf Ungleichheiten? Wie wirkt Geschlecht in Prozessen auf dem Arbeitsmarkt und in Organisationen? Und welche Konsequenzen hat dies auf Liebes- und Paarbeziehungen sowie der Vereinbarkeit von Familie und Beruf?

column1: Im dritten Block betrachten wir unterschiedliche gesellschaftliche Felder aus einer geschlechter- und ungleichheitskritischen Perspektive. Wir richten den Blick auf Mä
column3: t und (queere) Elternschaften. Den Zusammenhang von Geschlecht und Migration diskutieren wir vor dem Hintergrund einer dauerhaften Care-Krise und der Entstehung globaler F&uuml

column4: ften, planend-disponierenden Mitarbeitenden sowie haupt- und nebenberuflichen, zumeist freiberuflichen Lehrenden differenziert. In den letzten Jahren lassen sich neue T&auml

column2: tigkeitsprofilen in der Erwachsenenbildung mit theoretischen Zug&auml

<td width=""210"">
1. Kursinhalt
<td width=""393"">
Die Vorlesung &bdquo
column6: ber die Formen und Regeln wissenschaftlichen Arbeitens geben. Dazu wird zun&auml
column9: berhaupt sind und warumman sich an feste Regeln und Formen zu halten hat. Offensichtlich gibt es etablierte akademisch-wissenschaftliche Konventionen, die ber&uuml
column11: ssen, um sich jenseits der gesprochenen Sprache verst&auml

column1: Neben den formalen Regeln fü
column2: r den Aufbau einer wissenschaftlichen Arbeit (Hausarbeit, B.A. und M.A.-Abschlussarbeit, Dissertation/Doktorarbeit bzw. alle anderen Formen der wissenschaftlichen Publikationen wie Monografien, Sammelb&auml
column4: tze in wissenschaftlichen Zeitschriften) geht es darum, sich auch einen wissenschaftlichen Sprachstil, einen &bdquo
column6: ,anzueignen, mit dem der Inhalt wissenschaftlicher Texte transportiert wird und mit dessen Hilfe die Fachkolleg*innen dieGedanken, Argumente und Aussagen eines Textes nachvollziehen k&ouml

column1: Wissenschaftliches Arbeiten bedeutet auch, konzentriert und diszipliniert (im Sinne der akademischen Disziplin/Fachrichtung) zulesen und sich den Text anzueignen. Nur wenn ein Text vollstä
column2: ndig verstanden wurde, er in eigenen Worten wiedergegeben unddie Aussage/These eines Textes in wenigen S&auml
column3: tzen zusammengefasst werden kann, ist die Lekt&uuml

column1: Sich
column2: Texte durch zielgerichtetes Lesen (und Denken, Reflektieren, Transfers leisten) zu erschlie&szlig
column5: ber das Lesen denAufbau und Inhalt wissenschaftlicher Abhandlungen zu verstehen und zu begreifen.

column1: Die Vorlesung ist komplementä
column2: rer Bestandteil zu den Regionalwissenschaftlichen Debatten, die alle Erstsemester zu belegen haben. Sie bietet die notwendige Grundlage, mit der am Ende des ersten Semesters die anstehende erste wissenschaftliche Hausarbeit geschrieben warden kann.
